verses.text: The king's heart is like a stream of water in the hand of the LORD; he directs it wherever he wills.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes God's sovereignty over rulers. No matter a king’s intentions, the Lord ultimately guides their decisions, reminding readers of God's control over history.

verses.text: Every way of a man is right in his own eyes, but the LORD weighs the hearts.
verses.comment: Humans often justify themselves, but only God truly knows people's motives. This calls for humility and a willingness to examine our consciences sincerely.

verses.text: To do righteousness and justice is more acceptable to the LORD than sacrifice.
verses.comment: God desires obedience from the heart more than outward religious ritual. Genuine acts of love and justice reflect a deeper relationship with God.

verses.text: Haughty eyes and a proud heart—the lamp of the wicked—is sin.
verses.comment: Pride is identified as a root of sin. Scripture consistently warns against arrogance, showing its spiritual dangers.

verses.text: The plans of the diligent lead surely to abundance, but everyone who is hasty comes only to poverty.
verses.comment: Diligence and prudent planning are commended. Hasty, reckless pursuits often result in failure.

verses.text: The getting of treasures by a lying tongue is a fleeting vapor and a deadly snare.
verses.comment: Dishonest gain offers only brief satisfaction but leads ultimately to ruin.

verses.text: The violence of the wicked will sweep them away, because they refuse to do what is just.
verses.comment: Violent people bring destruction upon themselves by rejecting justice. Justice is thus both a social and spiritual matter.

verses.text: The path of the guilty is crooked, but the conduct of the upright is straightforward.
verses.comment: Those who are right with God live with honesty and integrity, in contrast to the devious ways of the wicked.

verses.text: It is better to live in a corner of the housetop than in a house shared with a quarrelsome wife.
verses.comment: Peace within the home is of great value. Discord or habitual strife disrupts harmony in family life.

verses.text: The soul of the wicked desires evil; his neighbor finds no mercy in his eyes.
verses.comment: Wickedness corrupts desire, making one unmerciful to others. The heart’s disposition shapes external actions.

verses.text: When a scoffer is punished, the simple become wise; when the wise is instructed, he gains knowledge.
verses.comment: Correction is meant to benefit all: to warn the naive and help the wise grow in virtue.

verses.text: The Righteous One observes the house of the wicked; he brings the wicked to ruin.
verses.comment: God, the Righteous One, sees and judges all. Ultimate justice comes from Him, not just from human authority.

verses.text: Whoever shuts his ear to the cry of the poor will himself call out and not be answered.
verses.comment: Compassion for the poor is a divine expectation; indifference hardens one’s own heart toward God.

verses.text: A gift given in secret soothes anger, and a concealed bribe, strong wrath.
verses.comment: Secret gifts can appease wrath in interpersonal relationships. Not all gifts are evil, as context shows; generosity and prudence are necessary.

verses.text: When justice is done, it is a joy to the righteous but terror to evildoers.
verses.comment: Justice aligns with God’s will. It brings peace to the faithful and dread to the wicked.

verses.text: Whoever strays from the path of understanding will rest in the assembly of the dead.
verses.comment: Leaving the path of truth leads to spiritual death. This highlights the importance of sound doctrine and perseverance.

verses.text: Whoever loves pleasure will become poor; he who loves wine and oil will not become rich.
verses.comment: Addiction to luxury and indulgence leads to poverty. Moderation and discipline reflect a life ordered toward virtue.

verses.text: The wicked becomes a ransom for the righteous, and the faithless for the upright.
verses.comment: God delivers the upright from harm, sometimes allowing the wicked to suffer the fate intended for the just.

verses.text: It is better to live in a desert land than with a quarrelsome and vexing woman.
verses.comment: The importance of domestic peace is stressed repeatedly, pointing to the value of harmony within family life.

verses.text: Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man devours it.
verses.comment: Wisdom preserves and builds wealth, while folly squanders it. This principle can apply to both spiritual and material blessings.

verses.text: Whoever pursues righteousness and loyalty finds life, righteousness, and honor.
verses.comment: Virtue and steadfast love result in blessings of life and honor, reflecting the character God desires.

verses.text: A wise man scales the city of the mighty and brings down the stronghold in which they trust.
verses.comment: Wisdom is more powerful than brute strength. True strength comes from spiritual discernment.

verses.text: Whoever keeps his mouth and his tongue keeps himself from trouble.
verses.comment: Control over one's speech is a sign of spiritual maturity. Guarding words protects from many evils and leads to peace.

verses.text: Scoffer is the name of the arrogant, haughty man who acts with proud fury.
verses.comment: Pride and mockery are closely connected, and such attitudes distance people from God’s grace.

verses.text: The desire of the sluggard kills him, for his hands refuse to work.
verses.comment: Refusal to labor leads to destruction. Spiritual sloth (acedia) is also seen as a grave fault in the Christian tradition.

verses.text: All day long he craves and craves, but the righteous gives and does not hold back.
verses.comment: The selfless life of the righteous—marked by generosity—contrasts with the never-satisfied hearts of the lazy and greedy.

verses.text: The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; how much more when he brings it with evil intent!
verses.comment: External acts of worship without purity and right motivation are rejected by God. True worship requires holiness of life.

verses.text: A false witness will perish, but the man who listens will speak forever.
verses.comment: Truth endures, while lies are eventually exposed. The one who hears and embodies truth stands firm. Echoes Christ’s teaching about the importance of hearing and living out His words (Matt. 7:24).

verses.text: A wicked man hardens his face, but the upright establishes his way.
verses.comment: There is a contrast between stubborn evil and steadfast virtue. The upright’s certainty comes from walking in God’s truth, often with the help of spiritual guidance and tradition.

verses.text: There is no wisdom, no understanding, and no counsel against the LORD.
verses.comment: Ultimately, no human plan can prevail against God’s will. All wisdom finds its source and fulfillment in Him.

verses.text: The horse is prepared for the day of battle, but victory belongs to the LORD.
verses.comment: Effort and preparation are important, but success is determined by God’s providence. This foreshadows trust in divine aid, especially in spiritual battles.
